content: The "Next Generation Technology Innovation Awards Act of 2000" establishes awards for schools under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to promote next-generation technology innovation. The purpose of the "Next Generation Technology Innovation Awards Act of 2000" is to expand knowledge about advanced computers and telecommunications for teaching, address national questions about technology in education, and develop innovative technology models aligned with academic content for widespread adoption. The Secretary can award grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements for up to 5 years through the Office of Educational Technology to support innovative technology models aligned with academic content standards. "Eligibility for grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements under the Office of Educational Technology is outlined in SEC. 3212." To be eligible for an award under this part, a consortium must include a State or local educational agency and an institution of higher education, for-profit entity, museum, library, or other entity with relevant expertise. The applicant must submit a detailed project description and evaluation plan to the Secretary for consideration. The proposed project under this part must include a detailed plan for independent evaluation and may prioritize innovative models of educational technology and projects serving multiple states with large-scale technology innovations in education. Priority areas for projects under this part include serving multiple states with large-scale technology innovations, developing innovative models for underserved populations, providing substantial resources, using electronic networks for challenging courses, and establishing high-speed internet access. "SEC. 3213. USES OF FUNDS." "A recipient must use funds awarded under this part to develop new educational technology applications, integrate technology across the curriculum, and carry out other activities consistent with the purposes of this part, such as improving teachers' ability to integrate technology into course curriculum." Teachers can enhance their ability to integrate technology into course curriculum through high-quality professional development. This includes developing standards-based digital content like multimedia software, digital video, and web-based resources. It also involves utilizing new technological formats, computer modeling tools, visualization, simulation tools, and innovative methods for assessing student performance. The curr_chunk discusses the use of technology in education, including web-based learning curricula, digital libraries, and software for educational materials development. It also mentions making programs accessible to students with special needs. The curr_chunk focuses on using technology to support students with special needs, providing opportunities for female students in technology, and promoting school-family partnerships through parent education programs. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of parent education programs in supporting children's academic success, acquiring necessary technology resources, and collaborating with other government programs. The Secretary is authorized to develop tools, provide resources, offer technical assistance, conduct independent evaluations, and disseminate findings to promote effective models for evaluating the impact of educational technology. The recipient of funds under this part is limited to using no more than 3 percent of the funds for administrative costs or technical assistance. The Secretary may require recipients to share in the cost of activities assisted under an award, not exceeding 50% of the total cost. The non-Federal share may be in cash or in-kind contributions. The Secretary can increase the share after the first year of receiving funds. The required non-Federal share will be published in the Federal Register. Authorization of appropriations is also mentioned. "For fiscal year 2001 and the following four years, necessary sums are authorized to be appropriated. Repeal of former program for National Challenge Grants includes amendments to specific sections of the Act."
